elements.content: Luminescent metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have received much attention due to their applications in color displays, sensors, and smart materials. However, how to balance the energy distribution between singlet and triplet excited states for a new generation of persistent luminescent MOFs is still a challenging goal. In this work, we report that the construction of cluster-based MOFs can supply an effective way to modulate the fluorescence and room-temperature phosphorescence (RTP) emission based on adjustable π–π stacking, halogen-bonding interaction, and metal–cluster units. Compared to the pristine ligand (5-bromoisophthalic acid) with obvious spin–orbit coupling, Zn5 and Zn3 cluster-based MOFs exhibit tunable photoluminescence (such as fluorescence and RTP wavelength, lifetime, and quantum yield). The ultralong-lived RTP visualization and temperature-dependent luminescence also provide the Zn5 cluster-based MOF as a new type of anticounterfeiting and temperature-responsive phosphorescent switch material. Therefore, this work highlights the first example of cluster-based MOFs as ultralong-lived persistent luminescent materials for tuning singlet and triplet excited states, which may be extended to other similar systems for developing ultralong RTP and delayed fluorescence materials.
elements.clean_text: Luminescent metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received much attention due to their applications in color displays, sensors, and smart materials. However, how to balance the energy distribution between singlet and triplet excited states for a new generation of persistent luminescent MOFs is still a challenging goal. In this work, we report that the construction of cluster-based MOFs can supply an effective way to modulate the fluorescence and room-temperature phosphorescence (RTP) emission based on adjustable π-π stacking, halogen-bonding interaction, and metal-cluster units. Compared to the pristine ligand (5-bromoisophthalic acid) with obvious spin-orbit coupling, Zn5 and Zn3 cluster-based MOFs exhibit tunable photoluminescence (such as fluorescence and RTP wavelength, lifetime, and quantum yield). The ultralong-lived RTP visualization and temperature-dependent luminescence also provide the Zn5 cluster-based MOF as a new type of anticounterfeiting and temperature-responsive phosphorescent switch material. Therefore, this work highlights the first example of cluster-based MOFs as ultralong-lived persistent luminescent materials for tuning singlet and triplet excited states, which may be extended to other similar systems for developing ultralong RTP and delayed fluorescence materials.

elements.content: Persistent luminescent materials involving long-lived triplet-state energy levels have attracted much attention in recent years due to their applications in displays and safety signs, anticounterfeiting, in vivo bioimaging, chemical sensors, and so on. From the fundamental study and practical application viewpoints, the ability to modulate the energy distribution between singlet and triplet excited states is important to obtain new types of persistent luminescent materials. Current systems, including ultralong room-temperature phosphorescence (RTP) and delayed fluorescence, have been developed ranging from traditional inorganic compounds and organometallic complexes to current pure organic materials, carbon dots, multicomponent host–guest systems, and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). For molecular RTP materials, several mechanisms have been put forward to improve their RTP efficiency. For example, upon introduction of heavy atoms and/or aromatic carbonyl groups, spin–orbit coupling (SOC) can be promoted effectively to accelerate the intersystem crossing (ISC) between singlet and triplet excited states. Recently, An et al. have obtained enhanced ultralong RTP based on halogen-bond interactions (such as C–Br···OC, C–Br···π, C–Br···Br–C, and C–Br···H). However, to the best of our knowledge, how to further modulate halogen-bond interactions for balancing the excited singlet and triplet states and tuning fluorescence and phosphorescence is still a challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Persistent luminescent materials involving long-lived triplet-state energy levels have attracted much attention in recent years due to their applications in displays and safety signs, anticounterfeiting, in vivo bioimaging, chemical sensors, and so on. From the fundamental study and practical application viewpoints, the ability to modulate the energy distribution between singlet and triplet excited states is important to obtain new types of persistent luminescent materials. Current systems, including ultralong room-temperature phosphorescence (RTP) and delayed fluorescence, have been developed ranging from traditional inorganic compounds and organometallic complexes to current pure organic materials, carbon dots, multicomponent host-guest systems, and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). For molecular RTP materials, several mechanisms have been put forward to improve their RTP efficiency. For example, upon introduction of heavy atoms and/or aromatic carbonyl groups, spin-orbit coupling (SOC) can be promoted effectively to accelerate the intersystem crossing (ISC) between singlet and triplet excited states. Recently, An et al. have obtained enhanced ultralong RTP based on halogen-bond interactions (such as C-Br⋅⋅⋅OC, C-Br⋅⋅⋅π, C-Br⋅⋅⋅Br-C, and C-Br⋅⋅⋅H). However, to the best of our knowledge, how to further modulate halogen-bond interactions for balancing the excited singlet and triplet states and tuning fluorescence and phosphorescence is still a challenge.

elements.content: As another strategy, incorporation of RTP molecules into a relatively rigid environment (such as mechanisms involving crystallization-induced RTP and formation of host–guest systems) could also reduce the nonradiative decay of triplet excitons. In this context, MOFs, also known as porous coordination networks, in which organic ligands coordinate with metal ion–cluster units, have also emerged as promising systems to achieve ultralong-lived RTP emission for afterglow material applications. In the MOF structures, the organic ligands can be highly rigidified and restricted by the metal ions, and thus the n → π* transition in the carboxylate group can be accelerated effectively. Moreover, the main factors in the MOF structure (such as the nature of metal ions, the orientation and arrangement of organic linkers, and the coordination environment) would largely influence the intramolecular and/or intermolecular interactions among organic linkers that can affect the RTP properties. Additionally, the potential charge transfer between metal centers and the organic ligands may also tune the excited singlet and triplet states.
elements.clean_text: As another strategy, incorporation of RTP molecules into a relatively rigid environment (such as mechanisms involving crystallization-induced RTP and formation of host-guest systems) could also reduce the nonradiative decay of triplet excitons. In this context, MOFs, also known as porous coordination networks, in which organic ligands coordinate with metal ion-cluster units, have also emerged as promising systems to achieve ultralong-lived RTP emission for afterglow material applications. In the MOF structures, the organic ligands can be highly rigidified and restricted by the metal ions, and thus the n → π* transition in the carboxylate group can be accelerated effectively. Moreover, the main factors in the MOF structure (such as the nature of metal ions, the orientation and arrangement of organic linkers, and the coordination environment) would largely influence the intramolecular and/or intermolecular interactions among organic linkers that can affect the RTP properties. Additionally, the potential charge transfer between metal centers and the organic ligands may also tune the excited singlet and triplet states.

elements.content: Recently, taking advantage of both cluster nodes and organic linkers, cluster-based MOFs have attracted much attention and became a major pursuit in a new generation of MOF family, which have presented new applications, such as cancer therapy, luminescent sensors, CO2 conversion, and ion encapsulation and release. However, to the best of our knowledge, cluster-based MOFs with ultralong-lived persistent luminescence have not been reported yet, and whether the diversity of clusters could affect the singlet and triplet excited states in MOF materials is still a mystery. Benefitting from the multiple coordination modes and various assembly fashions of organic ligands with cluster nodes in cluster-based MOFs, we reasoned that the halogen-bond interactions may be adjusted in different spatial orientations for halogen-containing cluster-based MOFs, which could further modulate the SOC process and fluorescence/phosphorescence emission ().
elements.clean_text: Recently, taking advantage of both cluster nodes and organic linkers, cluster-based MOFs have attracted much attention and became a major pursuit in a new generation of MOF family, which have presented new applications, such as cancer therapy, luminescent sensors, CO2 conversion, and ion encapsulation and release. However, to the best of our knowledge, cluster-based MOFs with ultralong-lived persistent luminescence have not been reported yet, and whether the diversity of clusters could affect the singlet and triplet excited states in MOF materials is still a mystery. Benefitting from the multiple coordination modes and various assembly fashions of organic ligands with cluster nodes in cluster-based MOFs, we reasoned that the halogen-bond interactions may be adjusted in different spatial orientations for halogen-containing cluster-based MOFs, which could further modulate the SOC process and fluorescence/phosphorescence emission ().

elements.content: Schematic illustration of three kinds of spatial orientations between two Br atoms in the nearest ligand pair, resulting in different SOC, π–π stacking modes, and luminescence processes in H2BIPA, Zn5 and Zn3.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic illustration of three kinds of spatial orientations between two Br atoms in the nearest ligand pair, resulting in different SOC, π-π stacking modes, and luminescence processes in H2BIPA, Zn5 and Zn3.

elements.content: With the aim to integrate halogen-bond interactions into cluster-based MOFs, in this work, we chose a unique organic phosphor, 5-bromoisophthalic acid (H2BIPA) as the model ligand. H2BIPA presents high-efficiency ISC with stronger RTP emission than fluorescence. By design of two new Zn-cluster-based MOFs, pentanuclear [Zn5(BIPA)4MIM­(OH)2(H2O)2] (Zn5) and trinuclear [Zn3(BIPA)2(MIM)3(OH)2]·2H2O (Zn3) (MIM = 2-methylimidazole), we found that it is possible to adjust the energy distribution between singlet and triplet excited states, relative to the pristine H2BIPA. Combining X-ray single crystal analysis and theoretical calculation on Zn5 and Zn3, the modulation of halogen-bond interactions and Zn-clusters is responsible for the seperation of singlet and triplet energy states. Moreover, the Zn5-cluster MOF can further serve as an “on–off” phosphorescent switch responding to temperature. Therefore, this work not only provides a proof of concept for cluster-based MOFs as ultralong-lived RTP materials for potential anticounterfeiting and temperature sensor applications, but also deepens the understanding on the relationship between the spatial halogen-bond interactions and fluorescent/phosphorescent properties.
elements.clean_text: With the aim to integrate halogen-bond interactions into cluster-based MOFs, in this work, we chose a unique organic phosphor, 5-bromoisophthalic acid (H2BIPA) as the model ligand. H2BIPA presents high-efficiency ISC with stronger RTP emission than fluorescence. By design of two new Zn-cluster-based MOFs, pentanuclear [Zn5(BIPA)4MIM(OH)2(H2O)2] (Zn5) and trinuclear [Zn3(BIPA)2(MIM)3(OH)2]⋅2H2O (Zn3) (MIM = 2-methylimidazole), we found that it is possible to adjust the energy distribution between singlet and triplet excited states, relative to the pristine H2BIPA. Combining X-ray single crystal analysis and theoretical calculation on Zn5 and Zn3, the modulation of halogen-bond interactions and Zn-clusters is responsible for the seperation of singlet and triplet energy states. Moreover, the Zn5-cluster MOF can further serve as an "on-off" phosphorescent switch responding to temperature. Therefore, this work not only provides a proof of concept for cluster-based MOFs as ultralong-lived RTP materials for potential anticounterfeiting and temperature sensor applications, but also deepens the understanding on the relationship between the spatial halogen-bond interactions and fluorescent/phosphorescent properties.

elements.content: Zn3- and Zn5-cluster-based MOFs were synthesized by a hydrothermal reaction, and their structures have been fully characterized by X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis (, , and S2 and Tables S1–S4 in the Supporting Information). The Zn5-cluster MOF crystallizes in monoclinic space group P 21/ n (No. 14). In its fundamental unit (a), five Zn­(II) cations with different coordination geometries are bridged by two μ3-OH– groups generating a pentanuclear [Zn5(μ3-OH)2]8+ cluster (b). Zn1 and Zn3 ions display a distorted tetrahedral geometry surrounded by one μ3-OH– and three carboxylate-O from different BIPA2– ligands. Zn2 shows a distorted tetrahedral geometry composed of one μ3-OH–, two carboxylate-O, and one N donor from MIM. Zn4 exists in distorted trigonal-bipyramidal geometry, being coordinated by two carboxylate-O from different BIPA2– ligands, two μ3-OH–, and one bridging μ2-H2O. Zn5 has one more coordinated water molecule than Zn4, resulting in a distorted octahedronal geometry. Moreover, pentanuclear zinc clusters are extended by the BIPA2– ligands to construct a rare two-dimensional (2D) double-layer open-framework structure (c). The 2D layers further stack to form a three-dimensional (3D) structure by π–π stacking of the outwardly extending ligands (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Analysis

Zn3- and Zn5-cluster-based MOFs were synthesized by a hydrothermal reaction, and their structures have been fully characterized by X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis (, , and S2 and Tables S1-S4 in the Supporting Information). The Zn5-cluster MOF crystallizes in monoclinic space group  P 21/ n  (No. 14). In its fundamental unit (a), five Zn(II) cations with different coordination geometries are bridged by two μ3-OH- groups generating a pentanuclear [Zn5(μ3-OH)2]8+ cluster (b). Zn1 and Zn3 ions display a distorted tetrahedral geometry surrounded by one μ3-OH- and three carboxylate-O from different BIPA2- ligands. Zn2 shows a distorted tetrahedral geometry composed of one μ3-OH-, two carboxylate-O, and one N donor from MIM. Zn4 exists in distorted trigonal-bipyramidal geometry, being coordinated by two carboxylate-O from different BIPA2- ligands, two μ3-OH-, and one bridging μ2-H2O. Zn5 has one more coordinated water molecule than Zn4, resulting in a distorted octahedronal geometry. Moreover, pentanuclear zinc clusters are extended by the BIPA2- ligands to construct a rare two-dimensional (2D) double-layer open-framework structure (c). The 2D layers further stack to form a three-dimensional (3D) structure by π-π stacking of the outwardly extending ligands (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environments of Zn­(II) ions; (b) pentanuclear Zn5 cluster (symmetry codes: A = −x + 1, y, z; B = x + 1/2, −y + 3/2, z – 1/2; C = −x + 3/2, −y + 3/2, z – 1/2); and (c) 2D double-layer open-framework structure of Zn5, viewed along the c axis as a polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation; C: gray, O: red, N: blue, Zn: green, and Br: purple.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination environments of Zn(II) ions; (b) pentanuclear Zn5 cluster (symmetry codes: A = -x + 1, y, z; B = x + 1/2, -y + 3/2, z - 1/2; C = -x + 3/2, -y + 3/2, z - 1/2); and (c) 2D double-layer open-framework structure of Zn5, viewed along the c axis as a polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation; C: gray, O: red, N: blue, Zn: green, and Br: purple.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environments of Zn­(II) ions; (b) trinuclear Zn3 cluster (symmetry codes: A = −x + 1, −y + 1, −z); and (c) 2D layered structure of Zn3, viewed along the [101] axis as a polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation; C: gray, O: red, N: blue, Zn: green, and Br: purple.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Coordination environments of Zn(II) ions; (b) trinuclear Zn3 cluster (symmetry codes: A = -x + 1, -y + 1, -z); and (c) 2D layered structure of Zn3, viewed along the [101] axis as a polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation; C: gray, O: red, N: blue, Zn: green, and Br: purple.

elements.content: In Zn3, two symmetry-related μ3-OH– groups connect three Zn­(II) ions to form a [Zn3(μ3-OH)2]4+ cluster subunit (a). The fundamental unit includes two BIPA2– ligands, three MIM ligands, and two H2O. As shown in b, each Zn­(II) adopts a distorted trigonal-bipyramidal coordination mode, Zn1 consists of three carboxylate-O from two different BIPA2– ligands, one μ3-OH–, and one N donor from MIM. Zn2 is coordinated by two carboxylate-O from two different BIPA2– ligands, two μ3-OH– groups, and one N donor from MIM. As shown in c, the carboxylate groups of BIPA2– ligands interconnect the [Zn3(μ3-OH)2]4+ secondary building blocks into a 2D layered structure along the crystallographic [101] axis. There are π–π stacking interactions between the 2D layered structures (intralayer π–π interactions), which further produce a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure S2b in the Supporting Information), in which the water molecules occupy the void spacing. Additionally, scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Figure S3 in the Supporting Information) shows that both of the Zn3 and Zn5 MOF crystals present microsized bulky morphology with a smooth surface.
elements.clean_text: In Zn3, two symmetry-related μ3-OH- groups connect three Zn(II) ions to form a [Zn3(μ3-OH)2]4+ cluster subunit (a). The fundamental unit includes two BIPA2- ligands, three MIM ligands, and two H2O. As shown in b, each Zn(II) adopts a distorted trigonal-bipyramidal coordination mode, Zn1 consists of three carboxylate-O from two different BIPA2- ligands, one μ3-OH-, and one N donor from MIM. Zn2 is coordinated by two carboxylate-O from two different BIPA2- ligands, two μ3-OH- groups, and one N donor from MIM. As shown in c, the carboxylate groups of BIPA2- ligands interconnect the [Zn3(μ3-OH)2]4+ secondary building blocks into a 2D layered structure along the crystallographic [101] axis. There are π-π stacking interactions between the 2D layered structures (intralayer π-π interactions), which further produce a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure S2b in the Supporting Information), in which the water molecules occupy the void spacing. Additionally, scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Figure S3 in the Supporting Information) shows that both of the Zn3 and Zn5 MOF crystals present microsized bulky morphology with a smooth surface.

elements.content: For the pristine H2BIPA solid, the prompt photoluminescence (PL) spectrum presents a small peak at 440 nm and three major peaks located around 509 nm; notably, the emissive peaks in the delayed PL spectrum are nearly overlapped with the prompt ones, suggesting the highly effective RTP emission band. Upon formation of cluster-based MOFs, Zn5 presents similar RTP emission to H2BIPA, but totally different fluorescence emission with a major peak at 485 nm and shoulder peaks at 430/463 nm. For Zn3 MOF, both fluorescence (445 nm) and RTP (500 nm) present blue-shifted emission relative to those of the Zn5 system (a). The CIE 1931 color coordinate values of prompt spectra for these compounds (b and Table S5 in the Supporting Information) further show their tunable photoemission in the blue/green region. Moreover, both Zn5 and Zn3 exhibit reduced RTP quantum yield (QY) values of 11.12 and 1.23%, respectively, compared to H2BIPA (13.94%) ( and S6 in the Supporting Information), which are consistent with the enhanced fluorescence for Zn3 and Zn5 MOFs. The RTP QY value of Zn5 is higher than that of most of the as-reported MOFs. Therefore, the coordination of BIPA phosphors with Zn3 or Zn5 clusters can largely tune the energy distribution between singlet and triplet excited states relative to the pristine molecular crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Long-Lived RTP Emission Properties

For the pristine H2BIPA solid, the prompt photoluminescence (PL) spectrum presents a small peak at 440 nm and three major peaks located around 509 nm; notably, the emissive peaks in the delayed PL spectrum are nearly overlapped with the prompt ones, suggesting the highly effective RTP emission band. Upon formation of cluster-based MOFs, Zn5 presents similar RTP emission to H2BIPA, but totally different fluorescence emission with a major peak at 485 nm and shoulder peaks at 430/463 nm. For Zn3 MOF, both fluorescence (445 nm) and RTP (500 nm) present blue-shifted emission relative to those of the Zn5 system (a). The CIE 1931 color coordinate values of prompt spectra for these compounds (b and Table S5 in the Supporting Information) further show their tunable photoemission in the blue/green region. Moreover, both Zn5 and Zn3 exhibit reduced RTP quantum yield (QY) values of 11.12 and 1.23%, respectively, compared to H2BIPA (13.94%) ( and S6 in the Supporting Information), which are consistent with the enhanced fluorescence for Zn3 and Zn5 MOFs. The RTP QY value of Zn5 is higher than that of most of the as-reported MOFs. Therefore, the coordination of BIPA phosphors with Zn3 or Zn5 clusters can largely tune the energy distribution between singlet and triplet excited states relative to the pristine molecular crystals.

elements.content: (a) Normalized prompt (blue) and decayed (green) PL spectra (λex = 365 nm) at room temperature; (b) corresponding CIE 1931 color coordinates of three compounds; (c) phosphorescence decay curves and lifetime of H2BIPA (green), Zn5 (red), and Zn3 (blue); and (d) photos of samples before and after turning off UV light.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Normalized prompt (blue) and decayed (green) PL spectra (λex = 365 nm) at room temperature; (b) corresponding CIE 1931 color coordinates of three compounds; (c) phosphorescence decay curves and lifetime of H2BIPA (green), Zn5 (red), and Zn3 (blue); and (d) photos of samples before and after turning off UV light.

To further detect the excited states of pristine H2BIPA and cluster-based MOFs, PL decay curves have been measured. At room temperature, Zn5 crystal has longer fluorescence lifetime (3.011 ns) and RTP lifetime (7.041 ms) than both Zn3 MOF (τ­(F) = 2.488 ns; τ­(P) = 3.155 ms) and H2BIPA crystals (τ­(F) = 1.441 ns; τ­(P) = 4.372 ms) ( and c). Their different RTP decay is also reflected in the apparent color changes before and after removing the UV lamp (d). When H2BIPA, Zn5 and Zn3, MOFs were excited under UV irradiation at 365 nm, green and blue emissions can be observed. After the removal of the UV source, the samples present different RTP emissions. Particularly for Zn5 MOF, the color changed obviously from blue to green and slowly faded with different decay times (d), confirming its ultralong-lived afterglow emission behavior. Such property may allow us to use cluster-based MOFs as luminescent anticounterfeiting materials.
elements.clean_text: To further detect the excited states of pristine H2BIPA and cluster-based MOFs, PL decay curves have been measured. At room temperature, Zn5 crystal has longer fluorescence lifetime (3.011 ns) and RTP lifetime (7.041 ms) than both Zn3 MOF (τ(F) = 2.488 ns; τ(P) = 3.155 ms) and H2BIPA crystals (τ(F) = 1.441 ns; τ(P) = 4.372 ms) ( and c). Their different RTP decay is also reflected in the apparent color changes before and after removing the UV lamp (d). When H2BIPA, Zn5 and Zn3, MOFs were excited under UV irradiation at 365 nm, green and blue emissions can be observed. After the removal of the UV source, the samples present different RTP emissions. Particularly for Zn5 MOF, the color changed obviously from blue to green and slowly faded with different decay times (d), confirming its ultralong-lived afterglow emission behavior. Such property may allow us to use cluster-based MOFs as luminescent anticounterfeiting materials.

elements.content: To understand the origin of the different PL features of two Zn-cluster MOFs relative to the H2BIPA ligand, single-crystal analysis was also carried out on pristine H2BIPA. The H2BIPA molecules in crystals present typical face-to-face π–π stacking (central distance: 3.86 Å), with the orientational angle of ca. 61.7° between the dimers (). Such face-to-face arrangement corresponds to H-type aggregation, which has been proved to promote the RTP emission. Moreover, the Ph–Br bonds are parallel to each other with a Br···Br distance of 4.07 Å; the halogen-based heavy-atom layer and hydrogen-bonding layer alternatively appear in H2BIPA (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). Such a stacking fashion corresponds to the strong heavy-atom effect and high orbital overlapping for halogen-bonding interactions, which are beneficial for the acceleration of SOC and ISC processes. For Zn-cluster MOFs, the π–π stacking modes of ligands are similar to those of pristine H2BIPA, with the distances between adjacent BIPA units of 3.46, 3.58, 3.72, and 4.26 Å in Zn5 and 4.05 Å in Zn3. However, the different crystal stacking modes lead to diverse intermolecular interactions (Figures S6, S7 and Table S7 in the Supporting Information). In Zn3 MOF, the orientation between the adjacent Ph–Br bond presents in an opposite direction between the ligand dimer (d Br···Br = 4.96 Å), which could largely decrease the electronic coupling between Br atoms in aromatic chromophores and weaken the intermolecular halogen-bonding interactions (such as C–Br···H and C–Br···OC) (Figure S6 and Table S7 in the Supporting Information). Such a structural change is consistent with the appearance of obvious fluorescence for the Zn3 MOF. As for Zn5, it contains three different orientations of Ph–Br units (), as a result of multicoordination sites in the Zn5-cluster structure. The complicated multiorientations dominated in the systems would also decrease the heavy-atom effect and weaken the halogen interactions between Ph–Br units relative to the pristine ligands, which correspond to two major fluorescence bands in the PL spectra. Therefore, the alternation of the ligand interactions through the formation of cluster-based MOFs may provide an effective way to redistribute the energy between singlet and triplet excited states for molecular phosphor materials.
elements.clean_text:
Relationship between Structure and Fluorescence/Phosphorescence

To understand the origin of the different PL features of two Zn-cluster MOFs relative to the H2BIPA ligand, single-crystal analysis was also carried out on pristine H2BIPA. The H2BIPA molecules in crystals present typical face-to-face π-π stacking (central distance: 3.86 Å), with the orientational angle of ca. 61.7° between the dimers (). Such face-to-face arrangement corresponds to H-type aggregation, which has been proved to promote the RTP emission. Moreover, the Ph-Br bonds are parallel to each other with a Br⋅⋅⋅Br distance of 4.07 Å; the halogen-based heavy-atom layer and hydrogen-bonding layer alternatively appear in H2BIPA (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). Such a stacking fashion corresponds to the strong heavy-atom effect and high orbital overlapping for halogen-bonding interactions, which are beneficial for the acceleration of SOC and ISC processes. For Zn-cluster MOFs, the π-π stacking modes of ligands are similar to those of pristine H2BIPA, with the distances between adjacent BIPA units of 3.46, 3.58, 3.72, and 4.26 Å in Zn5 and 4.05 Å in Zn3. However, the different crystal stacking modes lead to diverse intermolecular interactions (Figures S6, S7 and Table S7 in the Supporting Information). In Zn3 MOF, the orientation between the adjacent Ph-Br bond presents in an opposite direction between the ligand dimer (d Br⋅⋅⋅Br = 4.96 Å), which could largely decrease the electronic coupling between Br atoms in aromatic chromophores and weaken the intermolecular halogen-bonding interactions (such as C-Br⋅⋅⋅H and C-Br⋅⋅⋅OC) (Figure S6 and Table S7 in the Supporting Information). Such a structural change is consistent with the appearance of obvious fluorescence for the Zn3 MOF. As for Zn5, it contains three different orientations of Ph-Br units (), as a result of multicoordination sites in the Zn5-cluster structure. The complicated multiorientations dominated in the systems would also decrease the heavy-atom effect and weaken the halogen interactions between Ph-Br units relative to the pristine ligands, which correspond to two major fluorescence bands in the PL spectra. Therefore, the alternation of the ligand interactions through the formation of cluster-based MOFs may provide an effective way to redistribute the energy between singlet and triplet excited states for molecular phosphor materials.

elements.content: To better understand the photophysical properties and electronic structures of Zn5 and Zn3 cluster-based MOFs, we carried out periodical density functional theoretical (PDFT) calculations. For Zn5 (), frontier orbital analysis indicates that the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) are mainly populated on the Br atom of BIPA2–, while the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) focus on the phenyl groups of BIPA2–. Therefore, photoexcitation and emission may be generated by the charge-transfer process of the interligand with C–Br···π interactions. The computational results indicate that the Br atoms have played an important role in the frontier orbital distributions and may increase the separation time of electron–hole pairs during the charge-transfer process, thus confirming the heavy-atom effect on the modulation of the luminescence in Zn5. While in Zn3 (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information), the HOMOs and LUMOs are located in both the BIPA2– ligands and Zn-cluster units. Therefore, we can modulate the electronic structures of the organic phosphors to some extent by coordinating with Zn-clusters. The change in electronic structures may further affect the optical properties, as observed in the experiment.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Study

To better understand the photophysical properties and electronic structures of Zn5 and Zn3 cluster-based MOFs, we carried out periodical density functional theoretical (PDFT) calculations. For Zn5 (), frontier orbital analysis indicates that the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) are mainly populated on the Br atom of BIPA2-, while the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) focus on the phenyl groups of BIPA2-. Therefore, photoexcitation and emission may be generated by the charge-transfer process of the interligand with C-Br⋅⋅⋅π interactions. The computational results indicate that the Br atoms have played an important role in the frontier orbital distributions and may increase the separation time of electron-hole pairs during the charge-transfer process, thus confirming the heavy-atom effect on the modulation of the luminescence in Zn5. While in Zn3 (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information), the HOMOs and LUMOs are located in both the BIPA2- ligands and Zn-cluster units. Therefore, we can modulate the electronic structures of the organic phosphors to some extent by coordinating with Zn-clusters. The change in electronic structures may further affect the optical properties, as observed in the experiment.

elements.content: HOMOs (a), LUMOs (b), and total density of states/partial density of states (c) profiles for Zn5 as obtained by PDFT calculations (H in white; O in pink; C in gray; Zn in light green; N in blue; and Br in purple).
elements.clean_text: 5  HOMOs (a), LUMOs (b), and total density of states/partial density of states (c) profiles for Zn5 as obtained by PDFT calculations (H in white; O in pink; C in gray; Zn in light green; N in blue; and Br in purple).

elements.content: To develop potential heat-sensitive persistent luminescent materials, temperature-dependent spectra of the Zn5 MOF with the highest RTP quantum yield were further recorded (a,d). As the temperature increased, the reduced intensity indicates the dual-mode luminescence switching performance for the Zn5 MOF. For the fluorescence mode, the fluorescence intensity between 160 and 420 K can be fitted by a quadratic function (b). Additionally, there is an obvious decrease in the intensity from 140 to 160 K compared to other temperature ranges, suggesting that a critical temperature exists between 140 and 160 K for phonon–electron coupling or phonon–exciton coupling, which makes the fluorescence near 430 and 470 nm more sensitive to temperature. Furthermore, temperature-related recycling emission behavior between 300 and 380 K can be observed for its fluorescence spectra (c). d shows that when the temperature is reduced from 300 K (ambient condition) to 77 K, the phosphorescence emission peak at around 510 nm increased gradually. Compared to those at room temperature, the Zn5 crystal exhibits a new peak (λem = 430 nm) in its phosphorescence spectrum at 77 K, disclosing that other nonradiative routes are competing with the triplet state radiation at room temperature, and these nonradiative routes could be prohibited at cryogenic temperature. By lowering the temperature, molecular rotation within the solid matrix is greatly restrained, and the PL intensity is hence dramatically enhanced. The phosphorescence intensity at 500 nm presents a linear relationship with temperature between 140 and 300 K (e). Upon further increasing the temperature from 300 to 380 K, both the intensity (Figure S10a in the Supporting Information) and the phosphorescence lifetime (Figure S10b in the Supporting Information) at 510 nm decreased dramatically. Such behavior could be attributed to the massive nonradiative loss and violent molecular vibrations at high temperature, and several other organic phosphor systems also show similar behaviors. Moreover, when Zn5 was cooled down back to 300 from 380 K, it was observed that the delayed phosphorescence (PL) intensity can almost recover its original state spontaneously, and the reversible phosphorescence changes repeatedly between the “dark” and “bright” states at least five times during heating–cooling cycles (f).
elements.clean_text:
Temperature-Responsive Phosphorescent Switches

To develop potential heat-sensitive persistent luminescent materials, temperature-dependent spectra of the Zn5 MOF with the highest RTP quantum yield were further recorded (a,d). As the temperature increased, the reduced intensity indicates the dual-mode luminescence switching performance for the Zn5 MOF. For the fluorescence mode, the fluorescence intensity between 160 and 420 K can be fitted by a quadratic function (b). Additionally, there is an obvious decrease in the intensity from 140 to 160 K compared to other temperature ranges, suggesting that a critical temperature exists between 140 and 160 K for phonon-electron coupling or phonon-exciton coupling, which makes the fluorescence near 430 and 470 nm more sensitive to temperature. Furthermore, temperature-related recycling emission behavior between 300 and 380 K can be observed for its fluorescence spectra (c). d shows that when the temperature is reduced from 300 K (ambient condition) to 77 K, the phosphorescence emission peak at around 510 nm increased gradually. Compared to those at room temperature, the Zn5 crystal exhibits a new peak (λem = 430 nm) in its phosphorescence spectrum at 77 K, disclosing that other nonradiative routes are competing with the triplet state radiation at room temperature, and these nonradiative routes could be prohibited at cryogenic temperature. By lowering the temperature, molecular rotation within the solid matrix is greatly restrained, and the PL intensity is hence dramatically enhanced. The phosphorescence intensity at 500 nm presents a linear relationship with temperature between 140 and 300 K (e). Upon further increasing the temperature from 300 to 380 K, both the intensity (Figure S10a in the Supporting Information) and the phosphorescence lifetime (Figure S10b in the Supporting Information) at 510 nm decreased dramatically. Such behavior could be attributed to the massive nonradiative loss and violent molecular vibrations at high temperature, and several other organic phosphor systems also show similar behaviors. Moreover, when Zn5 was cooled down back to 300 from 380 K, it was observed that the delayed phosphorescence (PL) intensity can almost recover its original state spontaneously, and the reversible phosphorescence changes repeatedly between the "dark" and "bright" states at least five times during heating-cooling cycles (f).

elements.content: (a) PL spectra of Zn5 recorded in the temperature range of 77–420 K; (b) PL intensity of Zn5 in the temperature range of 77–420 K (inset: polynomial fitting curve at 470 nm); (c) reversible variation of the PL intensity for Zn5 at 300 and 380 K; (d) delayed PL spectra of Zn5 measured in the temperature range of 77–380 K; (e) delayed PL intensity of Zn5 in the temperature range of 77–380 K (inset: linear fitting curve at 470 nm in red and 500 nm in blue); and (f) reversible variation of the delayed PL intensity of Zn5 (500 nm) at 300 and 380 K.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) PL spectra of Zn5 recorded in the temperature range of 77-420 K; (b) PL intensity of Zn5 in the temperature range of 77-420 K (inset: polynomial fitting curve at 470 nm); (c) reversible variation of the PL intensity for Zn5 at 300 and 380 K; (d) delayed PL spectra of Zn5 measured in the temperature range of 77-380 K; (e) delayed PL intensity of Zn5 in the temperature range of 77-380 K (inset: linear fitting curve at 470 nm in red and 500 nm in blue); and (f) reversible variation of the delayed PL intensity of Zn5 (500 nm) at 300 and 380 K.

elements.content: By comparing the fluorescence and phosphorescence color changes of Zn5 at different temperatures (Figure S11 in the Supporting Information), the phosphorescence exhibits an obvious change in a wider range, suggesting that the phosphorescence mode is more sensitive for this cluster-based MOF. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) further reveals that the weight loss from 200 to 380 °C for Zn5 is related to the escaping of MIM at the surface and that the structure collapsed up to 380 °C (Figure S12a in the Supporting Information). The position of the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) peak remains basically the same after heating–cooling cycles (Figure S13 in the Supporting Information). From these evidences, it can be seen that Zn5 has high optical and thermal stability, which ensures that phosphorescence can be reversibly converted at high/low temperatures. Therefore, the Zn5 MOF could be applied as a promising dual-mode (fluorescence and phosphorescence) temperature-responsive switch.
elements.clean_text: By comparing the fluorescence and phosphorescence color changes of Zn5 at different temperatures (Figure S11 in the Supporting Information), the phosphorescence exhibits an obvious change in a wider range, suggesting that the phosphorescence mode is more sensitive for this cluster-based MOF. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) further reveals that the weight loss from 200 to 380 °C for Zn5 is related to the escaping of MIM at the surface and that the structure collapsed up to 380 °C (Figure S12a in the Supporting Information). The position of the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) peak remains basically the same after heating-cooling cycles (Figure S13 in the Supporting Information). From these evidences, it can be seen that Zn5 has high optical and thermal stability, which ensures that phosphorescence can be reversibly converted at high/low temperatures. Therefore, the Zn5 MOF could be applied as a promising dual-mode (fluorescence and phosphorescence) temperature-responsive switch.

elements.content: In summary, this work illustrates that balancing the singlet and triplet excited states can be achieved by the design of cluster-based MOFs, as a result of tunable relative orientation of the organic phosphor ligands. The fluorescence and phosphorescence (such as wavelength, PL lifetime, and quantum yield) of Zn5 and Zn3 can be modulated compared to pristine molecular phosphors. Considering the analysis results of theoretical calculations and single-crystal structure, we conclude that π–π stacking, halogen-bonding interaction, and metal–cluster units could largely influence the energy distribution of singlet and triplet states. Moreover, the Zn5 MOF exhibits ultralong-lived afterglow emission, and the visualization of different colors of fluorescence/phosphorescence also provides an opportunity for potential anticounterfeiting applications. Furthermore, it presents temperature-dependent fluorescence and phosphorescence, which may serve as a heat-responsive dual photoemission switch from 300 to 380 K. Therefore, this work not only provides new types of cluster-based MOFs with tunable fluorescence and phosphorescence by modulation of spatial orientations between phosphor ligands, but also supplies a temperature-responsive phosphorescence switch for sensor applications. It is expected that the strategy to modulate excited singlet and triplet states can be extended to other cluster-based MOF systems for the design of persistent luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, this work illustrates that balancing the singlet and triplet excited states can be achieved by the design of cluster-based MOFs, as a result of tunable relative orientation of the organic phosphor ligands. The fluorescence and phosphorescence (such as wavelength, PL lifetime, and quantum yield) of Zn5 and Zn3 can be modulated compared to pristine molecular phosphors. Considering the analysis results of theoretical calculations and single-crystal structure, we conclude that π-π stacking, halogen-bonding interaction, and metal-cluster units could largely influence the energy distribution of singlet and triplet states. Moreover, the Zn5 MOF exhibits ultralong-lived afterglow emission, and the visualization of different colors of fluorescence/phosphorescence also provides an opportunity for potential anticounterfeiting applications. Furthermore, it presents temperature-dependent fluorescence and phosphorescence, which may serve as a heat-responsive dual photoemission switch from 300 to 380 K. Therefore, this work not only provides new types of cluster-based MOFs with tunable fluorescence and phosphorescence by modulation of spatial orientations between phosphor ligands, but also supplies a temperature-responsive phosphorescence switch for sensor applications. It is expected that the strategy to modulate excited singlet and triplet states can be extended to other cluster-based MOF systems for the design of persistent luminescent materials.

elements.content:
Details of the experimental procedures are reported in the Supporting Information.

The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acsami.8b11039.

PXRD patterns of simulated and as-synthesized Zn5 and Zn3 (Figure S1); 3D network of Zn5 and Zn3 viewed along the a axis and [101] direction, respectively, as a ball-and-stick representation (Figure S2); scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image for Zn5 and Zn3 (Figure S3); fitting goodness for the phosphorescence lifetime values of H2BIPA, Zn5 and Zn3, in order (Figure S4); halogen-bonding interactions in H2BIPA, heavy-atom-based halogen-bonding layer, and hydrogen-bonding layer in pristine H2BIPA (Figure S5); halogen-bonding interactions in Zn3 MOF (Figure S6); halogen-bonding interactions in Zn5 MOF (Figure S7); electron-density distributions of various orbitals in Zn5 (Figure S8); electron-density distributions of various orbitals in Zn3 (Figure S9); phosphorescence spectra (a) and time-resolved emission decay curves (b) of Zn5 at 300 and 380 K (Figure S10); fluorescent and phosphorescent CIE 1931 of Zn5 at different temperatures (Figure S11); thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of Zn5 and Zn3 (Figure S12); PXRD patterns before and after heating Zn5 to 380 K (Figure S13); crystallographic data and structure refinement details for Zn5 (Table S1); selected bond distances and bond angles for Zn5 (Table S2); crystallographic data and structure refinement details for Zn3 (Table S3); selected bond distances and bond angles for Zn3 (Table S4); CIE 1931 color coordinates of H2BIPA, Zn5 and Zn3, at room temperature (Table S5); comparison of RTP QY values in this work with as-reported MOF systems (Table S6), and different kinds of halogen bond and the bond lengths in H2BIPA, Zn5 and Zn3 (Table S7) (PDF)

metadata.title:
Cluster-Based Metal–Organic Frameworks: Modulated
Singlet–Triplet Excited States and Temperature-Responsive Phosphorescent
Switch
